awd_titl_txt: Modeling motor behavior in the lobster stomatogastric system
awd_abstract_narration:
PROJECT TITLE: Modeling Motor Behavior in the Lobster Stomatogastric System

PI: Scott L. Hooper

PROJECT NUMBER: IOS 0958926

Understanding how nervous systems generate behavior is a central goal of neuroscience, and much about how nervous systems work is now known. However, this knowledge is insufficient to understand how behavior is produced because nervous systems drive muscles, which in turn move the effectors (typically limbs) that produce behavior. Different muscles respond differently to nervous system input, and limbs with different anatomies respond differently to given amounts of muscle activation. Since neuro-muscular systems evolve as a unified whole, nervous system properties will vary as a function of muscle and limb properties. Understanding how nervous systems generate behavior thus requires studying the muscles and limbs that nervous systems control. The proposed work will address this issue in an extremely well-understood nervous system, the nervous system that drives the movements of the lobster stomach. The lobster stomach is more similar to vertebrate limbs than to human stomachs in that it has neurally-driven muscles and bone-like effectors called ossicles. The neural output and make-up of the stomach nervous system are completely described and a great deal about the electrical properties of its neurons is known. The stomach muscles have individual and complex responses to neural input, and a quantitative, three-dimensional description of the stomach ossicles is available. All information necessary to connect nervous system make-up and output to behavior is thus available in this system. The proposed work will characterize muscle, ossicle, and joint properties in detail so as to allow later development of a computational model of the generation of behavior in this system. Due to the analogous natures of behavior generation in this and many other systems noted above, conclusions from this work should be widely applicable, including to understanding how human nervous systems generate movement. The proposed work will also provide training on both undergraduate and post-doctoral levels.

por.por_cntn:
We investigated lobster and stick insect leg muscles. Muscles transform nervous system activity into movement. Understanding how nervous systems generate behavior thus requires understanding how muscles respond to motor neuron input. We worked in lobster and stick insect because in these species much is known about their nervous system activity. A deeper understanding of their muscles would thus allow connecting nervous system activity to behavior.

Our research developed as we obtained additional data, and thus covered somewhat different topics than those in the proposal. We nonetheless achieved many aspects of its general goal, developing quantitatively accurate understanding of muscle properties. We first investigated how muscles passively (i.e., when the muscle's motor neurons are silent) generate force when stretched. Previous hypotheses had attributed this ability to background binding between the molecules (actin and myosin) that generate muscle active force. We showed that passive forces remain even when interactions between these molecules are blocked. Passive force must thus arise from other mechanisms. Muscles (triceps) are passively stretched, and thus generate opposing force, when their antagonists (biceps) contract. Understanding how these forces develop is therefore important for understanding behavior. Our data showing that these forces are not due to actin-myosin interactions should help research in this area across preparations.

We next developed, in collaboration with Büschges' lab at the University of Cologne, a quantitative model of a stick insect muscle. This work showed that the muscles varied greatly across individual animals, with model accuracy increasing some 25% when individual specific, rather than average, values were used in the models. This may not seem surprising—after all, having only average size clothing would not work very well—but it has two important implications. First, these differences mean that the muscles have different responses to the same motor neuron input. Our data thus indicate that each individual’s nervous system must be tuned to her/his specific muscle properties so that the individual's nervous system can drive the muscle appropriately to produce a desired movement. Second, it means that researchers must be able to measure all the characteristics that define muscles in single experiments, since they cannot average these data across animals. Muscles are defined by such a large number of parameters that is difficult to measure them all in single experiments. We developed protocols to overcome this difficulty and demonstrated how to utilize them in a real system. This work should help in building models for understanding how neuromuscular systems function.

Our third research area was the response of stomatogastric muscles to temperature changes. This work was undertaken because lobsters experience large temperature variations as they move about, prior work has shown that muscle responses vary greatly with temperature, and Marder and her co-workers have shown that certain aspects of stomatogastric nervous activity do not vary with temperature. We showed that stomatogastric muscles are highly temperature sensitive, stopping contraction when warmed only a few degrees (well within the physiological temperature range of the animals). This seemed odd, since intact animals continued to digest food (what the stomatogastric system does) even at warm temperatures. We showed that a likely explanation for this apparent discrepancy is that a modulatory substance known to be present in lobsters, dopamine, counteracts the effects of temperature. This work suggests that modulation may in sometimes not function to change activity, but instead to maintain it when internal state (in this case, temperature) changes.
